content: The Act is titled the "Aviation Employee Screening and Security Enhancement Act of 2017" and includes definitions for various terms. The "Aviation Employee Screening and Security Enhancement Act of 2017" defines key terms such as Administration, Administrator, air carrier, and appropriate congressional committees. The "Aviation Employee Screening and Security Enhancement Act of 2017" defines key terms such as appropriate congressional committees, foreign air carrier, and intelligence community. The "Aviation Employee Screening and Security Enhancement Act of 2017" defines key terms including foreign air carrier, intelligence community, and secured area. The "Aviation Employee Screening and Security Enhancement Act of 2017" defines key terms such as intelligence community, secured area, security identification display area, and sterile area. The "Aviation Employee Screening and Security Enhancement Act of 2017" defines terms like Security Identification Display Area and Sterile Area as per section 1540.5 of title 49, Code of Federal Regulations. SEC. 3. COST AND FEASIBILITY STUDY. The Administrator must conduct a cost and feasibility study within 180 days of the Act's enactment, in collaboration with the Aviation Security Advisory Committee. The study will assess the impact of implementing secure doors with card and pin entry or biometric technology at various airports. A cost and feasibility study will assess the impact of implementing secure doors with card and pin entry or biometric technology at Category I, II, III, IV, and X airports. The study will also include surveillance video recording, advanced screening technologies like magnetometers, explosives detection canines, and explosives trace detection swabbing. The study will include surveillance video recording for at least 30 days and advanced screening technologies such as magnetometers, explosives detection canines, explosives trace detection swabbing, advanced imaging technology, and x-ray bag screening technology. It will focus on employee screening costs at Category I, II, III, IV, and X airports. The study will include costs of employee screening at airports with 100% employee screening in secured areas, including establishing entry and exit points and comparing costs and effectiveness. The study will assess costs and effectiveness of employee screening at airports with 100% screening in secured areas, including entry and exit points, and compare these costs to the Federal Government and the aviation community. The Comptroller General of the United States will review the study on the costs and effectiveness of implementing security features at airports, comparing the impact on the Federal Government and the aviation community. The Comptroller General of the United States will review the study on airport security features' costs and effectiveness and report the results to relevant committees within 60 days. SEC. 4. AIRPORT WORKER EDUCATION AND SECURITY AWARENESS. The Administrator will collaborate with various stakeholders to improve security awareness among airport workers regarding insider threats and access controls. Additionally, credentialing standards will be established in consultation with air carriers and airport operators. The Administrator will assess credentialing standards for airport populations to address insider threats to aviation security within 180 days of the Act's enactment. A report will be issued within 30 days of completion. The Administrator, labor unions, and the Aviation Security Advisory Committee evaluate credentialing standards to address insider threats to aviation security. A report must be submitted to congressional committees within 30 days of completing the assessment. Social security numbers are required for SIDA applications within 60 days of the Act's enactment. The Administrator must report assessment results to congressional committees. Airport operators must submit social security numbers for SIDA applications within 60 days of the Act's enactment to enhance security vetting. Non-compliance may result in denial of credentials. The Administrator requires airport operators to submit social security numbers for individuals applying for access to the Security Identification Display Area to improve security vetting. Failure to provide the social security number may result in denial of the credential. Additionally, airport operators must include a screening notice in applications for access to the Security Identification Display Area. The Administrator mandates airport operators to submit social security numbers for security vetting of individuals applying for access to the Security Identification Display Area. Failure to provide the number may result in denial of the credential. Additionally, applicants are informed that employees with access to the area may be screened at any time. The Administrator requires airport operators to submit social security numbers for security vetting of individuals applying for access to the Security Identification Display Area. Failure to provide the number may result in denial of the credential. Employees with access to the area may be screened at any time. The Administrator collaborates with airport operators and the Aviation Security Advisory Committee to identify advanced technologies, including biometric identification, for securing employee access to airport secured and sterile areas. Additionally, within 180 days of the Act's enactment, all credentialed aviation workers requiring fingerprint-based criminal record checks will be continuously vetted through the FBI's Rap Back Service to swiftly detect and address insider threats to aviation security. The Administrator will ensure continuous vetting of aviation worker populations through the FBI's Rap Back Service to detect insider threats swiftly. Additionally, means of leveraging resources for insider threat education will be identified within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Administrator will enhance the Administration's ability to educate personnel on insider threats to aviation security and mitigate such threats. Playbook operations will be targeted and strategic to ensure the highest level of security effectiveness. The Administrator will conduct covert testing of employee inspection operations at airports to measure security effectiveness and provide results to the airport. The Administrator will conduct covert testing of employee inspection operations at airports to measure security effectiveness and provide results to the airport, air carriers, and foreign air carriers. Recommendations and technical assistance will also be offered. The Administrator will conduct covert testing of employee inspection operations at airports to measure security effectiveness and provide results, recommendations, and technical assistance to airport operators, air carriers, and foreign air carriers. Annual reports will be submitted to congressional committees for fiscal years 2018 through 2022. The Administrator will establish a national database of individuals for airport employee inspections. Annual reports on inspection operations will be submitted to congressional committees for fiscal years 2018 through 2022. The Administrator will establish a national database of individuals with revoked airport badges for non-compliance with security requirements. Reporting mechanisms will be determined for airlines and airport operators to submit data to the Administration. The national database will include individuals with revoked airport badges for non-compliance with security requirements. Reporting mechanisms will be established for airlines and airport operators to submit data and access the database. A process will be set up for individuals mistakenly entered into the database to correct their records and have their names removed. The Department of Homeland Security leads insider threat coordination at airports, working with other government entities, air carriers, and airport operators. They make efforts to investigate and mitigate insider threats. Additionally, there are provisions for information technology security. The Administrator must submit a plan for recurring reviews of security controls for airport IT systems within 90 days of this Act. No extra funds are authorized for these requirements. SEC. 8. NO ADDITIONAL FUNDS AUTHORIZED. No extra funds are authorized for the requirements of this Act, which will be carried out using existing amounts.
